Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "added support for display markdown licence files as HTML, fixes #7975" (#8151) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This adds support for displaying markdown files as HTML. A few notes:

* The ReadmeService.GetReadMeHtml should probably be refactored to factor out the MD -> HTML conversion. I have run out of time to do this

* The `CommonMark` library has a weird bug that if a string begins with a BOM, it doesn't convert the first line properly. As a result I stripped it out and then it works ok. It looks like the version of CommonMark used is old, and the package is also depreciated, but I don't have time to fix this either.

* Arguably there could also be another test added for converting licence MD files to HTML, I also haven't done this 

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7975

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add feature flag enable embedded readme file " (#8119) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

* add feature flag to enable embedded readme file during development

Addresses https://github.com/nuget/engineering/issues/2342

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Restore.csproj failed to build while running dotnet tool install dotnet-ef" (#9876) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: I had ef 3.0.0 and advised to update to 3.1.0. Direct update failed so I uninstalled ef from dotnet tool and tried to reinstall it again. I got error while building a restore project in path like this: [/var/folders/gt/9l4q1djd12d__wt0cxkqyrc80000gn/T/gkjf01jk.whw/restore.csproj] I passed verbosity option for detailed (--v d) with install command and it seems there is exception at NuGet.Protocol.ServiceIndexResourceV3Provider.GetServiceIndexResourceV3(SourceRepository source, DateTime utcNow, ILogger log, CancellationToken token) I am not sure this is an actual bug or this is a problem with my environment. I am running on macos 10.15.6 and dotnet 3.1.302. This is happened also if I downgrade to dotnet 3.1.100.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet should use TargetFrameworkMoniker & TargetPlatformMoniker to infer the frameworks instead of using the individual TFI, TFV, TPI, TPV properties" (#9895) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Update GetReferenceNearestTargetFrameworkTask  to support target frameworks with platforms (such as .NET 5-windows)" (#9894) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "[SSL/Transport Error] Unable to restore master branch with 5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10" (#9893) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/aspnetcore#24722**
- Please respond to @tebeco.

---

_From @tebeco on Sunday, August 9, 2020 6:51:32 PM_

Hello everyone ;)

### Describe the bug
As I am trying to restore the repository I'm hit by

```
C:\dev\github\tebeco\aspnetcore\.dotnet\sdk\5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10\NuGet.targets(128,5): error : Unable to load the service index for source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json.
C:\dev\github\tebeco\aspnetcore\.dotnet\sdk\5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10\NuGet.targets(128,5): error :   The SSL connection could not be established, see inner exception.
C:\dev\github\tebeco\aspnetcore\.dotnet\sdk\5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10\NuGet.targets(128,5): error :    Received an unexpected EOF or 0 bytes from the transport stream.
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2266487/89739398-a4933000-da80-11ea-8fb8-a45c1d7923f1.png)

It's the second day in a row it happens, and only at the end of the say, not sure if it's related to an outage or a cache somewhere, or ISP ...
The workaround described bellow only worked for less than 24h I would say, and worked again today

### To Reproduce
Follow the docs :
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/master/docs/BuildFromSource.md
```
> mkdir temp1234
> cd temp1234
> git clone --recursive https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore
> cd aspnetcore

> ./eng/scripts/InstallVisualStudio.ps1 -Channel Preview
> npm i -g yarn
> ./restore.cmd
fails
```
I've just update Windows Insider Dev channel, and I hope there's nothing broken about Certificate :D
Hello everyone ;)

### Describe the bug
As I am trying to restore the repository I'm hit by

```
C:\dev\github\tebeco\aspnetcore\.dotnet\sdk\5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10\NuGet.targets(128,5): error : Unable to load the service index for source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json.
C:\dev\github\tebeco\aspnetcore\.dotnet\sdk\5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10\NuGet.targets(128,5): error :   The SSL connection could not be established, see inner exception.
C:\dev\github\tebeco\aspnetcore\.dotnet\sdk\5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10\NuGet.targets(128,5): error :    Received an unexpected EOF or 0 bytes from the transport stream.
```

### To Reproduce
Follow the docs :
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/master/docs/BuildFromSource.md
```
> mkdir temp1234
> cd temp1234
> git clone --recursive https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore
> cd aspnetcore

> ./eng/scripts/InstallVisualStudio.ps1 -Channel Preview
> npm i -g yarn
> ./restore.cmd
fails
```
I've just update Windows Insider Dev channel, and I hope there's nothing broken about Certificate :D

### More digging
It seems to fail on `dotnet tool restore` (At first)
Yesterday I had the exact same issue
* ran `dotnet tool restore`  => takes VERY LONG TIME => same error
* deleted `global.json` => `dotnet tool restore` => went weird because `dotnet/arcade`
* `dotnet nuget locals --clear all` => same issue

### Workaround
Editing `global.json` to use `preview7` (because, well I also use `preview7` on side project)
From:
```json
{
  "sdk": {
    "version": "5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10"
  },
  "tools": {
    "dotnet": "5.0.100-rc.1.20379.10",
...
```
To preview7
```json
{
  "sdk": {
    "version": "5.0.100-preview.7.20366.6"
  },
  "tools": {
    "dotnet": "5.0.100-preview.7.20366.6",
```

At that time `restore.cmd` works and if I `git checkout global.json` and re-run `restore.cmd` it works again.
I don't get it

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version
  `master` (commit `983e7ed635f4d128edce4191b51869bd7be8aced`)

- Include the output of `dotnet --info`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2266487/89739414-d3a9a180-da80-11ea-8d67-4474d1dc68db.png)

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version
  `master` (commit `983e7ed635f4d128edce4191b51869bd7be8aced`)

- Include the output of `dotnet --info`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackCommand_PackProject_AddsProjectRefsAsPackageRefs is failing on latest dev" (#9892) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Feature request - Option to update user cache automatically after successful pack" (#9891) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used: NuGet.exe | VS UI
NuGet version 5.6.0.6591
VS version 16.6.3
OS version Windows Server 2019

1. Setup 2 solutions each with a project so that one project has a package reference to the other. Project A depends on Project B via nuget package reference. Set GeneratePackageOnBuild to true in Project B.

2. Make changes to project B and build it. 
Then go back to Project A and rebuild it. The previous change in project B is not reflected in project A.

Expectation: The change in project B should reflect in project A so I can test it and finally check in.

Suggested feature:
When the nupkg is generated for project B after successful build, it should (optionally) update the nuget user cache as well, overwriting if the same version already exists.

Local package source option doesn't work either as it would require increasing version every time project B is changed. If version is not increased it would use the older code of the same version from the nuget cache. After the successful testing, I would normally check in and the package version would be increased.

Keeping both projects in the same solution is also not a good idea, as that would mean all the projects referencing project B should be in the same solution as B which defeats the purpose of nuget reference.

Workaround:
We ended up implementing a custom target that deletes the package in the nuget cache and updates it with the newly built pack. It would nice to have this feature built in.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "GeneratePathProperty should automatically populate package path variables for package dependencies transitively" (#9889) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): **msbuild16 using PackageReference in csproj**

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): **msbuild16**

VS version (if appropriate): 

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: **No, didn't work**

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

When GeneratePathProperty is specified in a PackageReference, please populate package path variables for that package's dependencies transitively. We have run into issues where props/targets files associated with the package in the PackageReference need path variables for package dependencies and they are not populated correctly.

Setup:
- Nuget Package A that depends on Nuget Package B
- A targets file in Package A needs package path variable for Package B
- Application XYZ has PackageReference (with GeneratePathProperty="true") to Package A and uses the above targets file from Package A to build
- Package path variable for Package B is not populated and build fails

@rainersigwald 

...

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet Package Update Automation" (#9888) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I am facing an issue with automating NuGet package update operations.  These commands had leveraged the NuGet.Core library for automating the process of applying NuGet updates to project files, but that library looks to have long since been deprecated.  

There is an issue with upgrading netstandard2.0 packages within a project (TargetFrameworkVersion 4.7.2). The debug message flow from PackageManager is:

-----------------------------------------------
> Looking for updates for 'MYPACKAGE'...

> Updating 'MYPACKAGE' from version 'x.y.z' to 'a.b.c' in project 'MYPROJECT'.

> Removing 'MYPACKAGE x.y.z' from MYPROJECT.

> Added file 'packages.config'.
> Successfully removed 'MYPACKAGE x.y.z' from MYPROJECT.

> Adding 'MYPACKAGE a.b.c' to MYPROJECT.
-----------------------------------------------
At which point a "MYPROJECT does not reference 'MYPACKAGE'" error is thrown.


The project is still using packages.config file to manage its NuGet package references.  NuGet packages are used to split and package code from various modules which are consumed by an application project.  An automated process in Azure DevOps pipelines is used to update those packages and push out to a CI environment for testing.


I have looked at the following scenarios unsuccessfully on how to upgrade our process to support newer netstandard2.0 packages:

-----------------------------------------------
01: Update NuGet.Core version
-> Library is deprecated, no newer version to upgrade to

02: NuGet.exe version update (to version 5.6.0)
-> NuGet version update has no effect on underlying NuGet.Core code

03: Leverage built-in NuGet supported tasks within Azure DevOps
-> NuGet.exe CLI does not support our necessary functions
    -> .csproj file is not updated with assembly references
    -> Files contained within NuGet packages are not updated/extracted as anticipated

04: Leverage commands supported by Visual Studio NuGet Package Manager Console
-> Commands can only be run within Visual Studio (no support for automation from command line)

-----------------------------------------------


What options does NuGet currently support for updating/managing package installations in automated fashion (such as from a CLI)?
Is there an option that has feature parity with the Visual Studio Package Manager Console?

Are there any libraries that have superseded NuGet.Core for programmatically updating NuGet packages? 
Is there a recommended migration path (with accompanying documentation)?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cleaning up old binding redirects" (#9857) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/1092773/cleaning-up-old-binding-redirects.html)._

---
Over time the config files of my solution got a lot of obsolete binding redirects. To clean them up I had to manually remove the existing redirects and then run on the nuget powershell the command Add-BindingRedirect

wanting to automate the process for all my projects in the solution, I found the code here very helpful
https://martowen.com/2018/09/12/refreshing-net-assembly-binding-redirects-in-a-visual-studio-solution/

Please add to the nuget powershell a command like Remove-BindingRedirect in the URL above so this can be done within VS built-in commands and not rely on 3rd party code

Another option would be to enhance the Add-BindingRedirect command with a parameter that will instruct it to remove all existing redirects before executing

---
### Original Comments

#### Feedback Bot on 6/27/2020, 11:52 PM: 

Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion.  We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further.  We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "With multi targeted projects, NuGet should read the target framework related information from the inner build. " (#9756) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently in command line scenarios NuGet reads the target framework information in the outer build. 
That is incorrect because the the contract is that we should depend on on TargetFrameworkIdentifier and the like properties. 
We do that here: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/bd482514a87a0085f8eb8603842ee1cb3ca5f277/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Build.Tasks/NuGet.targets#L500-L526

This task is a blocker for https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5154. 

An incomplete list of things that need done are:

* In command line scenarios, read the framework in the inner build (this should allow us to read OS Version for example). 
* In VS scenarios, modify the VSSOlutionREstoreService to read the information from the properties back instead of the TargetFrameworks value. 
* Reflect all of the changes in the assets file (not sure if we'll need any). 

- [ ] Commandline restore (nuget.exe, msbuild.exe dotnet.exe).
- [ ] Commandline Static Graph restore.
- [ ] VS restore

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
